intro: Galium gracile f. hispidum, commonly known as the hairy woodypod, is a low-growing perennial herb native to parts of North America. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, often hairy stems and small, opposite leaves. The plant produces clusters of tiny, white to pale yellow flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its foliage and stems are covered in fine, soft hairs, giving it a distinctive appearance. It typically thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodland floors and stream banks.
